Award.AbstractNarration:
The electron density in the magnetosphere crucially affects a number of time-dependent phenomena such as the growth and propagation of whistler waves, chorus waves, and hiss. Chorus waves are thought to accelerate radiation belt electrons. The electron density can serve as a rough proxy for mass density, which affects the growth and propagation of ULF waves and the propagation of shock waves through the magnetosphere. Both of these phenomena can also accelerate radiation belt electrons, or cause their loss through pitch angle scattering.

This project will develop empirical models of the electron density in the magnetosphere. It will used data from a variety of satellite missions (IMAGE, POLAR, ISEE-1, CRRES). It will examine the field-line dependence of density by combining data from IMAGE and Polar. The project will develop models based on solar wind parameters. It will also examine how the electron density varies during magnetic storms.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
There were three major positive outcomes from this grant, the research findings, the groundwork laid for future research, and the training of students.

 The magnetosphere is the region of space surrounding the Earth in which the Earth’s magnetic field has a dominant effect. It is filled with particles called plasma. During the solar cycle, radiation from the Sun varies from low values at solar minimum to high values at solar maximum. Two competing processes affect the motion of material within the magnetosphere, corotation that causes material to rotate with the earth, and convection across the magnetosphere. When the material corotates, new particles from the region close to the earth called the ionosphere can come up magnetic field lines and fill these field lines with high density material. During solar maximum, there is a larger convection of material through the magnetosphere. We found that at solar minimum, the electron density is larger, probably because of better refilling due to less convection. On the other hand, the mass density is larger at solar maximum. This is due to the presence of the heavy ion O+ (singly charged oxygen). The larger solar radiation at solar maximum is helpful to allow the O+ to get higher in the ionosphere, and increased wave activity at solar maximum also helps to get the O+ up the magnetic field lines into the magnetosphere. The end result is a large variation in ratio of  O+ ions to electrons during the solar cycle.

 We also completed a major study of electron density refilling. While many other studies had investigated a small number of events with high refilling rates, we studied the typical refilling rates for electron density over a large range of distances from the center of the earth. Our results are being used in new density models and have been used for a check of simulation results.

 In the course of our study, we prepared databases of electron density measured by four different spacecraft missions spanning a total of 20 (non-contiguous) years. We categorized all the data into types such as high density plasmasphere and low density plasmatrough. These databases will be invaluable for future studies. One of these databases, spanning 13 years, has been retrieved from being totally lost on some old computers and has been distributed to other researchers.

 

We also developed techniques for statistical modeling using a large number of input parameters and a general modeling technique. We are using a genetic modeling algorithm to find by trial and error formulas that we would not even imagine.

 

Finally, we trained 10 students to do science. We taught these students the fundamentals of the inner magnetosphere, particularly in regards to magnetospheric density. And we taught them programming, statistical analysis, how to examine data and results to see if they are reasonable.

 


Last Modified: 09/12/2013
Modified by: Richard E Denton
